div1.p: Moran discusses his contact with the playwright Sidney Coe Howard. He suggests that Kean's impartiality would be best suited to help Howard. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

Jan. 20, 1932.
Gen. Jefferson R. Kean,
Army Medical Museum,
Washington, D. C.
My dear General:-
div1.p:
My sincere thanks for your letter of January
11th. Please accept my hearty congratulations upon pro-
motion, after retirement as I take it, to the rank of
Brigadier General. I was unaware of the fact until I
received your letter. No one rejoices more than I, your
loyal and devoted humble servant since 1899, that you have
been accorded a recognition which does you justice in part
at least. I shall never forget how you helped me out in
1899-1900 when Captain Quinton began to make things dis-
agreeable for me at Guanajay Barracks and you arranged for
my transfer to Columbia Barracks under Major Stark who
treated me more as a friend than as a subordinate. In the
years that you have devoted to the cause of those connected
with the yellow fever experiments, the debt of gratitude I
owe you has grown. I am sure you are convinced of my
sincerity.

With reference to Mrs. Agramonte's case. Last
evening, at our regular monthly meeting of the Legion, I
showed your letter to Major C. C. Fitzgerald and suggested
to him, as I had done on a previous occasion, that he write
the National Delegate in Washington of the Veterans of the
Spanish-American War to get in touch with as one of those
deeply interested in having Congress extend to Mrs. Agramonte
the benefits which her late husband enjoyed under the Act of
February 28, 1929. The Cuban unit of the Spanish-American
War Veterans got busy on behalf of Mrs. Agramonte shortly
following the doctors death. Major Fitzgerald promised
that he would write the National representative of the SAWV
to get in touch with you, so you may expect to hear from him.
Few Members of Congress have come to Cuba this year but Major
Fitzgerald, prominent here in the American Legion as well as
in the Spanish-American War Veterans, as well as myself, will
be on the lookout for any members of the National Legislature
who may drop in on us here.

On December 24th I received a letter from Mr. Sidney
Howard, Author-Dramatist, informing me that on your recommend-
ation he had talked with Mr. Parker about me and my connection
with the yellow fever experiments, and that he (Mr. Howard)
was desirous of coming to Havana for an interview with me and
would make the trip providing he could depend on my assistance
and cooperation in the preparation of his “story on yellow
fever”. I replied on the same day I received his letter and
told him that I was entirely at his service in a mission which
I considered laudable, material interest aside, but my letter
evidently went astray so that, to my great surprise and chagrin
I learned from his letter dated January 14th, between the lines
of which I could see that he was pained and injured at my fail-
ure to reply to his original letter, that my amiable reply to
his letter had not yet reached him. I can imagine that his
thoughts of me in the interim were not any too complimentary,
while I was entirely innocent of snobbishness or false pride
in connection with the object of his letter and mission. I
cabled him at once and forwarded a copy of my reply to his
original letter by air mail, receiving a cable from him day
before yesterday that he would be here on or about Friday, the
22nd instant. Have suggested to him that his notes should be
gone over by you. Perhaps he has already done so as he refers
to you as his friend. I also suggested that you were the one
impartial, living observer of the experiments, since all the
rest of us are inclined to view our particular share in the
experiements as paramount to the other man's participation and
share in same; that you know the underlying motives of each of
us who volunteered no matter what our individual opinions may
be. I am sure you are sufficient of a psychologist to qualify
in the premises. I want you to know that I include myself and
my share in the experiments in this opinion. If, therefore,
Mr. Howard visits you after he has had an opportunity to hear
my side of the story, I am sure you will be able to pick out
anything which he has written as coming from me which might
sound to you like a deviation from the truth. I would not want
you to spare me and should not feel in the least resentful as
a result of your “checking and correcting” any statement of
mine. I do not claim infallibility, and while my memory is
quite clear on what happened during those memorable two or
three months, I cannot lay claim to absolute unselfishness
when relating what I know. I have always tried to be honest
to myself and all the others concerned in this matter. While
your recollection of certain incidents may be in error, you
are by and large the one man best qualified to pass final
judgment on anything purporting to deal with the actual facts
surrounding the experiments and those connected with them.
For myself, I bow to that judgment.

Please remember me most kindly to Mr. Parker and
accept the homage and loyalty of
div1.closer:
Your humble servant, John J. Moran PLEASE OVERLOOK
MY VOLUBILITY.
